title: Do you think music can help someone who is struggling with a mental illness? - Quora

response.answer_text: Do you think music can help someone who is struggling with a mental illness? More than a year ago, during a hot and shiny summer, I was staying in a hotel together with a few friends. We've been there for a training. However bright the day was, however beautiful this summer turned out to be, my mind kept being troubled with somber, grey, almost terrifyingly dark, muddy fog. I'm a person with schizophrenia. I suffer from this illness for quite some years now but I'm doing rather good, so at that time I was reducing the dose of my meds. That brought back symptoms. They crept back into my life, slowly and steadily. During a break, I was sitting in some kind of lobby and got anxious. Not terribly so but still anxious. The voices started harassing me with their abusive choice of words and harsh sound. They got louder. And louder. And louder. Nobody could see it but within me, a battle took place. My confidence, without armour, against the voices, clad in iron, armed to the teeth. The voices always know what to say in order to hurt you. And then, Daniel started playing.  He didn't know I was struggling in this very minute. He just wanted to practice. He played for his own pleasure - and thereby won my battle for me. The sound of piano music calms me. It soothes my anxiety and redirects my mind to another thing, so it can push away the voices. Daniel saved my day back then. With his magical talent. He struck away the voices with every hit his fingertips pressed on the keys. I recorded him, so I can play it on demand. Of course I told him that I recorded him and why I did and that I would delete it immediately if he's not okay with that. But he's an angel who was glad to provide me with a new tool in my box of tricks, meant to keep me going. No other music ever helped me in that way. But piano music has an unimaginable therapeutic effect on me. Yes, my dear, I do think music can help people who struggle with mental illness.

Yes, not heal but help. When your mind is filled with chatter and ruminations and your stress level is climbing diversion helps. I play music almost all the time, whether I am writing or working out or whatever. I’m sure the people around me wish I would shut up, but I often sing aloud along with the music. Okay, I lied, I only do that when I am alone, I don’t want to be responsible for people running madly away, hands over their ears, into traffic or something. There is a certified therapy called music therapy, using music and talk therapy. That kind of music can go a long way to healing. What is Music Therapy | What is Music Therapy? | American Music Therapy Association (AMTA)

Well yes. In a few ways. Appreciating music is some kind of weird form of expression. Playing music or creating it? Even better. Music on it’s own is just supportive though. So let’s just say part of mental illness often involves some blockage or inhibition of expression of both emotions and creativity. Anything that allows feelings to come out and be recognized and acknowledged? That is helpful. And appreciation of music allows it. Some say dancing is one of the best ways to express yourself. It’s fun. According to Teal Swan? Great spiritual lady in Australia? Rap and hip hop actually stimulate your root chakra too. Certain sounds like the monks changing in tibet? Ohmmm? Just humming that can stimulate your Vagus nerve. This also helps depression somehow.

Dude, I’m a 7 year Army Veteran, who struggles with Schizophrenia, sure i’m not symptomatic now, the VA has me on some good drugs. Playing the guitar has been an outlet for me and a medical treatment for me. Sure I’ve played for 27 years, but once the VA got my meds right, I’ve been humming along on the strings. I used to medicate the disease with half gallons of vodka, let me tell you, that was the wrong approach, that lead to nothing but trouble with the law, jail, even imprisonment. So i seeked out help from the VA, it took 10 years of hospital stays, rehab, mental health counseling, therapy, groups, and of course med changes to finally get the right mix of therapy and meds. Now i go to the VA for 5 classes(Group Therapy) a week on Tuesdays and Thursdays for maintenance, but all other days are devoted to playing and learning the guitar, I want to goto college for classical guitar training(4 year degree from U C Cincinnati) I already have a degree in Electrical Engineering, so some of those credits will transfer for the basics, math, english, speech, ect.. ect.. but i have to have a 2 year music understudy before U C will accept me. Guitar is my life and I totally live for it, I use it to moderate my sickness and calm the voices from within. You say the guitar is there to help people with mental illnesses, I say “Ditto” It has helped me through the roughest times of my life!

Definitely, I was in music all my life playing in bands, orchestra and dancing while I was mentally ill. It was the balance to the insanity. Pick good classical music which is directly from the Creator and that energy brings sustaining power until you move into a higher consciousness of love and self honesty. I describe this in my book, “Paradigm Busters, Reveal the Real You” at Amazon. I was declared sane; it is possible.

Yes. The same way music can help someone NOT struggling with a mental illness. Music is a universal language, it can teach a psychopath about emotion, it can convey love between two parties who don't speak the same tongue, it can inspire peace between two rival gang leaders… if aliens ever visit us, I hope our first conversation is through fluid musical notes, rather contrived, rigid “words".

Yes it can. I have autism and schizophrenia. I use it for calming my mind. I listen to music while i work so i can focus on what i need to do. Then when i get home i use music to workout. I use music to sleep. Music is the one thing that is stable in my life. Everything else is not always as stable. So i choose one thing to hold onto and that is music.

The short answer is maybe. Sometimes I listen to music but I prefer silence often, tho it's not total silence 'cos there's always some background natural sound. Nothin' wrong with that. When I was really struggling with my depression, I didn't listen to music at all, but these kinds of things are very individualistic.

Yes I believe it is truly therapeutic, for a long time I didn’t want to listen to any music because it made me feel emotions I wasn't quite ready to deal with. So it kind of forces you to handle the issues and feel the emotions that you have been suppressing.

Don’t be absurd. How much time it must take in order to everyone understands that illness can be cured through a doctor, you mentioned illness so how do you think whether music is able to treat any illness? It doesn’t matter it’s mental one. Above all, it affects your mind, and if you listen to music to heal it, that’s a recipe for disaster.

It can help in the kind of way that a comfy chair with nice cushions might help someone's bad back, but no amount of music will cure mental illness any more than the nice chair will cure a bad back (though it might help it get better).
